DOC.HEAD: Heck's Selling Retail Operations in Six States
Eds: New throughout with comments from Heck's official.
DOC.TEXT: Heck's Inc., unable to turn a profit despite emerging from federal bankruptcy court protection, announced plans Friday to sell its retail operations, including 55 discount stores in six states, to New York-based Jordache Enterprises Inc. Faced with mounting debts that totaled $9 million since February, Heck's essentially decided to give away its retailers to a subsidiary of Jordache which in return will assume the chain's debts and longterm obligations, said Maartan Hemsley, Heck's chief operating officer. Heck's said in a statement it would receive ``nominal consideration'' in exchange for the Take 10 Discount Club stores in West Virginia, Virginia, Ohio, Kentucky, Pennsylvania and Tennessee, plus its headquarters building in Nitro, W.Va. and warehouses in Nitro and Poca, W.Va. Retail Acquisition Corp., the Jordache subsidiary, will assume all debts associated with the retail operations, including $22 million in mortgages and $3.5 million in annual rent, Heck's said. The deal is scheduled to be completed by spring. Hemsley said the company will move its headquarters to Pittsburgh and concentrate on its wholesale operation, which distributes automotive merchandise through its Steel City Products division. He said no more than one or two Heck's employees will be transferred to Pittsburgh. The fate of the remaining 2,000 Heck's employees won't be known until a definitive sale agreement is completed next month, he said. Heck's Chairman John Isaac Jr. said in a prepared statement that slow sales during the Christmas shopping season proved that the chain could not make enough money to keep the stores open. Operating losses for the quarter ended Nov. 25 were about $8 million, Issac said. Heck's, which once operated stores throughout the Southeast and Midwest, cut its employment from 5,900 to 2,000 and closed more than 100 stores from 1987 to 1989. When the company emerged from bankruptcy protection on Sept. 25, it changed the name of its stores to Take 10 Discount Club and instituted a ``membership'' program for additional discounts in an effort to attract customers. Heck's stock was traded on the New York Stock Exchange before its bankruptcy filing, and it once owned a discount shoe retailer, a string of women's apparel shops and a furniture store. Under the agreement announced Friday, Retail Acquisition Corp. will lease all Heck's retail properties from Jan. 31 to March 15, after which the sale will be completed, subject to approval by Heck's stockholders. As part of the agreement, Retail Acquisition agreed to buy all automotive merchandise for the former Heck's stores from the Steel City division for at least three years. This will be Jordache's entry into the discount retail market, Hemsley said. ``This is their first retail operation,'' he said. ``They had some prior involvement. But they haven't been in this kind of business at this time.''
